We are raising our full year 2010 forecast for non-GAAP total gross margin to a range of 41 to 44%, and for non-GAAP product gross margin to a range of 36% to 39%. For the 2010 total gross margin this represents a more than 5 percentage point increase in the mid-point of the range from the previous guidance.
Given our increased top line expectations for the year, we now expect non-GAAP operating expenses to be at the higher end of the range previously provided or approximately 750 million. For Q2 we forecast non-GAAP operating expenses of 180 to 190 million.
We now expect non-GAAP other income to be approximately 60 million for the year and we forecast the non-GAAP tax rate to remain at approximately 37%. We expect our 2010 Capital Investments to be at the higher end of the 700 to $900 million range, we previously provided and the estimated cash requirement for 2010 Capital Investments remains in the range of 300 to 400 million concentrated later in the year.
In summary, we are pleased with our first quarter performance and it is looking like 2010 will be a year in which we exceed the operating margin in our long-term financial model.
We'll now open the call for your questions.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. So, the OEM business is growing. I mean, we have said in the past that we believe we are now the third largest supplier now and certainly in the top three suppliers of OEM flash. And we believe that we have a tremendous room to grow, and talked about
componenttext:
Hi. So, the OEM business is growing. I mean, we have said in the past that we believe we are now the third largest supplier now and certainly in the top three suppliers of OEM flash. And we believe that we have a tremendous room to grow, and talked about very large, very broad front of design-ins, particularly for embedded products, and we see that as really just starting.
At the Analyst Day, we talked about AFM, thats the adopted flash management, which is part of our controller intelligence to allow us to optimized embedded flash to the specific application of the platform, and we're seeing very significant reception, productivity reception for that. So I would say that we probably have moved now quite solidly from a model where maybe a year ago or a little bit more than that we were maybe one third OEM and two-thirds retail to just opposite, one third retail and two-thirds OEM. And I dont - I expect to this thing is going to be with us for the foreseeable future.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And the other question is in terms of kind of the e-book and tablet markets and with your commentary that youre thinking of using some non-captive supply in the second half of the year. I mean how do you see those demand dynamics impacting the f
componenttext: Great. And the other question is in terms of kind of the e-book and tablet markets and with your commentary that youre thinking of using some non-captive supply in the second half of the year. I mean how do you see those demand dynamics impacting the flash memory markets and then specifically your usage of potentially moving to a little more non-captive?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So, the non-captive supply is very, very important in the long-term and we always said our model is to have 15 to 20% non-captive. However, it is also the case that with OEM becoming such a much stronger constituents portion of our output, Ive said man
componenttext: So, the non-captive supply is very, very important in the long-term and we always said our model is to have 15 to 20% non-captive. However, it is also the case that with OEM becoming such a much stronger constituents portion of our output, Ive said many times that OEM really cannot be satisfied through non-captive because you have to quote several quarters out and we really have to have control of our supply, so that really will very likely to the extent that we stay with this two-thirds OEM, one-third retail moving forward, or around that, our ability to employ non-captive will be reduced and we will have to use more captive supply.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tablets to the extent that you defined the iPod as a tablet and its competitors being more or less the same, we view that as a very, very important new platform that drives the demand for flash because it is really designed to be very thin, very long batt
componenttext:
Tablets to the extent that you defined the iPod as a tablet and its competitors being more or less the same, we view that as a very, very important new platform that drives the demand for flash because it is really designed to be very thin, very long battery life and therefore really relies on attributes of flash for storage.
The iPod is driving 64 gigabyte. We fully expect that the competition will be really driving at the 64 gigabyte and opening up to 128 and 256 gigabyte. This is very, very positive development for the NAND industry no matter who serves it, and also very important because again the Analyst Day we talked about thin is in.
What thin means when you have very thin products and you can't have a fan to cool the environment, you basically are driven to use modular flash which modular SSD which is SSD functionality but not necessarily in the 1.8 inch or 2.5 inch form factors, and that clearly plays to our strength because we have the ability to customize solid state disk to be basically to fit into very, very thin and any kind of profile which of course no disk drive can do.
So in that kind of environment people are starting to look at SSD not just is it lower - does it match the cost of hard disk drive but more is it enabling technology that allows that kind of form factor.

Thank you.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so there is a number of questions in that, so let me try and address those and Im sure there would be maybe a few other questions on that. So, Judy has indicated we're raising our guidance for the year from 4 billion to 4.4 to 4.5, 4.8. That's $5
componenttext:
Okay, so there is a number of questions in that, so let me try and address those and Im sure there would be maybe a few other questions on that. So, Judy has indicated we're raising our guidance for the year from 4 billion to 4.4 to 4.5, 4.8. That's $500 million additional revenues which of course would require very substantial additional gigabytes, petabytes and units that we are forecasting we will need flash for this year.
So of course the solution to getting that supply is from captive which is Fab 4, and then non-captive, and then anything we do with Fab 5 will definitely not have any impact.
It will not be available until really 2011 at the earliest.
So, this is what in my remarks I said we're striving to get our output this year to about 75% more bids this year, later in the year, and this comes from primarily greater efficiency in Fab 4, better yields than we had expected in Fab 4, as much utilization of X3 we can squeeze out of wafers and that's going very well and building some additional capacity in Fab 4 in the clean room space and there we're somewhat limited by equipment lead times and of course not much space left in there. So all of these in combination give you that 75% so increase and that may not be enough and in that case we will explore non-captive option.

componenttext: Yes, thank you. As you approach the CapEx decision along with your partner Toshiba, can you just talk to us a little bit about what's going into those discussions and also is there any chance that you may again revise the nature of the joint venture and the share of the JV that you own?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well. As you know, Paul, we announced more than two years ago in MOU with Toshiba and nonbinding memorandum of understanding with Toshiba for the creation of fab 5, and that of course ran into the recession that the whole industry and really was put on ho
componenttext:
Well. As you know, Paul, we announced more than two years ago in MOU with Toshiba and nonbinding memorandum of understanding with Toshiba for the creation of fab 5, and that of course ran into the recession that the whole industry and really was put on hold.
About a month ago, Toshiba announced that they will commence the construction of the shell in the KG. This is basically a decision to build just a building. And we certainly plan to continue the partnership that we have with Toshiba in fab 5. However, I also said in the past and we really feel very strongly that we need to play our part as best we can to maintain health in the industry by not bringing our new capacity - any new capacity that we have from any new sources too soon to the market that would be not good for us and of course, we can't control what our competitors are doing. But basically this for the last, I term last quarter is curbing our enthusiasm.
That said, we do need to - we do see demand for flash growing at a very strong pace both from the mobile and from other markets including SSD, and therefore we do - again, I have said on February 26, its not a question of if were going to participate in fab 5 but when, and to what extent and the timing and so on, and all of those have not yet been decided. And we will let you know when the decisions are being made.

componenttext: Thanks, guys, and fantastic job on the margins. Id just had a question given how the strong OEM sales have been. Do you get any sensor has this entered in to your discussion in terms of may be OEM pre-buying an anticipation of a shortage in the back half of the year? Have you kind of made some assumptions for that as you cleaned your backlog so to speak just the account for any possibility of pull-in of orders?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer it without indirectly. We do feel that you heard me say as saying that in the next decade we think that flash already bigger than you think and thats really based on the mobile in the way it's going as well as thats obviously there is
componenttext:
Let me answer it without indirectly. We do feel that you heard me say as saying that in the next decade we think that flash already bigger than you think and thats really based on the mobile in the way it's going as well as thats obviously there is two major new markets that are very, very early, so the industry will need to build additional capacity that doesnt exist. I think we all know that, and you know the key is really the timing of those because the return on investment by itself is tied to the timing.
Now, what that leads me to say is over the next several years there will be a period, I believe, of shortages of flash memory, and that will be times where people will understand, OEMs, particularly large OEMs, that flash is becoming very strategic to their business. You can view it as a commodity, but when you can't get it at any price because it is just not there because your demand far exceeds the available capacity of the industry, and the cumulative demand of all customers, then of course people will start wanting to secure for themselves some of that capacity, so I do expect some of that may happen.
Of course we don't know for a fact, but I would not be surprised if the strategic nature in the next few years is going to become effective. It's no secret flash is a very, very tough technology. There are very few companies that can really deliver leading-edge technology, very high volume, both from the technology and the manufacturing and the balance sheet. So the answer to your question is yes, I think there is going to be some of that but there are some OEMs will start taking steps to assure themselves of supply.

componenttext: We have legal agreements that afford us guaranteed access to capacity from several of our licensees. componenttextpreview: So I think the main driver for low capacity cards mostly MicroSD one or two be about amazingly there is a huge number of handsets in - in countries such as China, India, South America and so on, and Africa, where you can get a very good handset for $20 or
componenttext:
So I think the main driver for low capacity cards mostly MicroSD one or two be about amazingly there is a huge number of handsets in - in countries such as China, India, South America and so on, and Africa, where you can get a very good handset for $20 or $25 and those forms used to rely almost entirely on embedded flash, lower flash or non-capacity NAND flash and just in the last several quarters they seem to have switched in very large quantities to a card slot MicroSD in 1 or 2 gigabytes and play music and actually FM radio and they become now the music player and some of them for 25 bucks you have camera.
So traditionally, we expect that the 1 gigabyte and 2 gigabyte to even kind of disappear but it has come back because of these phenomena. We think it is here to stay, I mean for a long time.

componenttext: Craig, I would say that even how much of the cost reduction we were able to pull into the first quarter that in terms of sequential improvement in cost per bit, I expect that Q1 may be a quarter that is difficult to repeat, but relative to the other quarters, I dont necessarily expect much difference between the Q2, Q3, Q4 in the approximate level of cost decline and as I said, we expect the full year to reach a cost improvement at the high-end of our range of 30 to 40%.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I also wanted to follow-up on a previous question regarding, I guess some of the cost benefits that you guys might have going from sort of the 34 nanometer 3-bit to sort of 20 nanometer 2-bit, if you could just maybe elaborate little bit on that
componenttext: Okay. And I also wanted to follow-up on a previous question regarding, I guess some of the cost benefits that you guys might have going from sort of the 34 nanometer 3-bit to sort of 20 nanometer 2-bit, if you could just maybe elaborate little bit on that?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually we are 32 nanometer and some of our competitors [ph] are 34 nanometer. Actually it's only because people are talking about throwing numbers about what is 2X. Now we have 20 nanometer class which means whatever you want. It has a two in somewhere
componenttext:
Actually we are 32 nanometer and some of our competitors [ph] are 34 nanometer. Actually it's only because people are talking about throwing numbers about what is 2X. Now we have 20 nanometer class which means whatever you want. It has a two in somewhere in the number. Anyway from 32 nanometer - first of all, 32 nanometer from 43 nanometer is very substantial cost reduction, and particularly if you stay 3 bits to 3 bits, 43 nanometer X3 to 32 nanometer X3.
As we get to lower geometries more scaled, I am sure again I said before we expect the difficulty of implementing X3 will increase but we feel they were playing to our strength. So we fully expect that when we go to 24-nanometer we will be able to take our X3 with us without in anyway comprising performance.
So from 32 to 24 again pretty substantial cost reduction and basically you're looking at - we have said NAND is going to start slowing down and we truly believe that, but at the same time the industry and we are moving still at a pretty rapid pace and I would say that the end of scaling of NAND has probably been greatly exaggerated, maybe by us as well. So, actually it's looking a little bit better all the time and that of course would be very good news for SSD particularly.

componenttext: Initially it has been an uphill battle but it is getting better now because we have been able to demonstrate to very exhaustive OEM qualifications that the product is very, very good and further more through this AFM adaptable flash memory we can actually get very good performance with X3 and everybody understands that the cost benefits of that. So, I would say the efforts of the last year are beginning to bear fruit right now, and I think once we're over the hump that people will hold still to adopt X3.

componenttext: Yeah. Let me start with the second part of your question. At our analyst day at the end of February when I laid out the long-term financial model, I described that model as a model that we believe is optional over the long-term in order to balance growth and profit and cash flow. I said that in some years we expect that we will beat the long-term financial model and in some years we will miss it, so it is not my expectation to continue to adjust that long-term financial model, but rather aim for that over time and what I am saying is it looks like this year is a year where we can beat the long-term financial model. And I am sorry. What was the first part of your question?

componenttext: Hi, all. Thank you for taking my questions. First, I would like to understand more about your plan with regard to the non-captive supply. I expect that if we use non-captive in the second half of this year it will probably be modest amounts of non-captive but it is one factor that we are taking into account in our expectations of gross margins for the second half.

componenttextpreview: Yes, very much so. Certainly a big part of the SSD market will be OEM, very much so in OEM. They will of course be the retail space in retail it can be non-captive, but I have to say that for SSD we have a very substantial engineering effort and I could t
componenttext: Yes, very much so. Certainly a big part of the SSD market will be OEM, very much so in OEM. They will of course be the retail space in retail it can be non-captive, but I have to say that for SSD we have a very substantial engineering effort and I could tell you that its very, very focused on squeezing out the best performance from the flash that we know best which is on captive flash, so its very difficult to get the kind of performance that we feel we can deliver in an SSD environment at the low cost, very high performance, and great for liability we feel that the best approach is to use captive for that, even for retail.

componenttext:
Okay. And then, Eli, the question supply, if you look at equipment makers in a backlog of very little NAND equipment in the backlogs like photography there is something different about this time, this year, on NAND spending, you guys and others like Samsung have been very disciplined in placing even on shrink any increment spending.
So my question is there anything fundamentally different in terms of technology, EUV, not ready, and two year's time that's giving NAND makers a pause or discipline that we will be in this kind of spending behavior longer and if we do as supply, it will be added in very small increments like you have announced 10% kind of incremental capacity? Is there anything fundamentally different about this time?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No. And with regards to EUV, EUV still is quite away - away from a mass production and certainly for very high volume production. So I think the assumption is that the demand growth will overwhelm existing capacity and that new fabs that use existing, the
componenttext: No. And with regards to EUV, EUV still is quite away - away from a mass production and certainly for very high volume production. So I think the assumption is that the demand growth will overwhelm existing capacity and that new fabs that use existing, the photography and existing NANDs scaled to as far as it will go will have to be built to meet the demand in the next - I would say really two to five years.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to SanDisk Corporation's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. And at this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Jay Iyer, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Anthony, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining us on the call today are Doctor Eli Harari, Chairman and CEO of SanDisk; and Judy Bruner, Executive Vice President of Administration and CFO.Before we begin, please note that any non-GAAP financi
componenttext:
Thank you, Anthony, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining us on the call today are Doctor Eli Harari, Chairman and CEO of SanDisk; and Judy Bruner, Executive Vice President of Administration and CFO.
Before we begin, please note that any non-GAAP financial measures discussed during this call as defined by the SEC and Regulation G will be reconciled to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure. That reconciliation is now available along with supplemental schedules on our website at sandisk.com/IR.
In addition, during our call today, we'll make forward-looking statements. Any statement that refers to expectations, projections or other characterizations of future events, including financial projections and future market conditions, is a forward-looking statement. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed in these forward-looking statements. For more information, please refer to the risk factors discussed in the documents we file from time to time with the SEC, including our annual report on Form 10-K for fiscal 2009 and our subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. SanDisk assumes no obligation to update these forward-looking statements, which speak as of the date hereof.
With that, I will turn the call over to Eli.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and good afternoon, everyone. First quarter results were considerably better than we had expected. Our OEM business was the star of the quarter, driven by strong demand from our mobile customers as well as new channels and customers added
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and good afternoon, everyone. First quarter results were considerably better than we had expected. Our OEM business was the star of the quarter, driven by strong demand from our mobile customers as well as new channels and customers added in 2009.
Our OEM business accounted for 63% of total product revenue in Q1 and has been the stabilizing factor compensating for the first quarter seasonality in our Retail business, which has yet to recover from the economic downturn in the U.S. and Europe. Our focus in Retail continues to be to maximize profitability, while expanding into new geographies where we believe we are making steady inroads. 
In the mobile end market, we continue to see strong adoption of our iNAND embedded store solutions as well as mobile cards. Mobile has now grown to half of our product revenues compared to virtually nothing five years ago.
MicroSD has become the de facto standard for cards in mobile phones, and the marketplace has bifurcated into low capacity, one- and two-gigabyte microSD cards for low-end phones and high-capacity four- to 32-gigabyte microSD cards for high-end smartphones, and we believe we hold strong leadership position in both segments.
The mobile markets for Flash is still in its early days. Just to remind you, mobile apps hardly existed and Smartphones were hardly a household word just two years ago. The iPod, along with other similar products, is expected to drive demand for Flash memory, 64 gigabyte and higher capacities. Whether this demand comes in the form of embedded storage or removable cards, we are now well positioned in both categories.
We continue to gain traction with leading OEMs for our modular SST solutions, solid state disk, in netbook and tablet computers. In the first quarter, we also entered the retail solid state drive market with our G3 products.
At current NAND pricing levels, SSD solutions are still expensive. However, we believe this market, too, should drive very substantial consumption of high capacity flash as it becomes much more affordable. We expect this will occur with the advent of 20x nanometer flash memory technology in mass production next year and with 1x NAND-technology in 2012.
We are now advocating to our aggressive solid state disk technology roadmap that should take us to being a top-tier supplier as SSD adoption accelerates in netbooks, notebooks and tablet PC platforms in the years ahead.
On the operations and technology front, we are very pleased with the ramp of our 32-nanometer technology, as well as the continuing cost benefits that we see from broader built[ph]implementation of our 3-bits-per-cell X3 technology into our products, where we believe we are significantly ahead of competition.
In the first quarter, our cost per gigabyte declined by 14% sequentially, continuing our highly competitive cost structure. As for the industry environment, demand and supply appears to be in balance for 2010. For ourselves, we now expect our captive bit output to increase in 2010 over 2009 by approximately 75%, up from approximately 70% estimated previously with the upside coming late in the year from better productivity and Fab 4 expansion.
Last month, Toshiba announced their intention to commence construction of the shell for a new clean-room at Yokkaichi, that will eventually be Fab 5. We are evaluating the timing of our participation in Fab 5, and we will provide further details as they become available later in the year.
In summary, the first quarter was a very, very good start for 2010. With our leading technology, large scale manufacturing, diversified end markets, broad product portfolio, premium brand and a strong balance sheet, we have powerful momentum to capitalize on future opportunities, and we believe that in the coming decade Flash will be bigger than you think. 
I will now turn it over to Judy.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eli. We delivered our best ever first quarter results, driven by strong OEM demand, minimal price reduction and continued execution in product cost reduction and expense management. Our total product revenue was down sequentially by 13%, which
componenttext:
Thank you, Eli. We delivered our best ever first quarter results, driven by strong OEM demand, minimal price reduction and continued execution in product cost reduction and expense management. Our total product revenue was down sequentially by 13%, which was less than we had expected given historical Q1 seasonality and a 14-week fourth quarter. Our Retail business reflected normal seasonality with revenue down 27% sequentially, while our OEM revenue was down only 2% sequentially.
As a result, the Q1 mix of our product revenue was 63% OEM and 37% retail. Our retail revenue grew 7% year-over-year, and our OEM revenue increased 158%, reflecting strong demand in the mobile market and the new channels we added in 2009. Looking at our revenue by end market, our first quarter product revenue came 49% from the mobile phone market, up from 38% in the first quarter last year.
Retail demand continued to be soft in Europe and the U.S., while Asia retail sales increased sequentially from Q4 to Q1. We believe we maintained share in U.S. retail while we may have given up some share in low-priced USB products in Europe retail. In Asia, we benefited from strong consumer demand, as well as from our geographic expansion efforts.
Our first quarter OEM revenue benefited from strong demand in the mobile market and, in general, from new customers for mobile embedded solutions, cards, as well as wafers and components. Our overall ASP per gigabyte declined 7% in the first quarter, much less than in the previous first quarters, reflecting a healthy supply-demand balance.  And some of our 7% decline in ASP per gigabyte reflected the mix of products sold rather than price decreases. 
Our units sold, decreased 3% sequentially and grew 62% year-over-year. Average capacity remained fairly steady as the pricing environment has created strong demand for lower capacity units. Average capacity was down 4% sequentially and up 5% year-over-year. Our total gigabytes sold, declined 7% sequentially and grew 71% year-over-year.
Our license and royalty revenue was slightly stronger than we had forecasted at $93 million and now fully reflects our new license agreement with Samsung. Our first quarter non-GAAP total gross margin of 46.5% and non-GAAP product gross margin of 41.5% benefited from a better-than-anticipated pricing environment and also from stronger-than-forecasted OEM sales that resulted in recognizing more of our 32-nanometer 3-bit-per-cell production in first quarter results.
Our product gross margin improved sequentially from an underlying product gross margin of 36% in Q4 '09 to 41.5% in Q1, driven by a 14% sequential cost reduction on a per-gigabyte basis compared to our 7% decline in price per gigabyte.
Non-GAAP operating expenses of $172 million were down $20 million from the fourth quarter, reflecting a 13-week quarter compared to Q4's 14 weeks, as well as seasonality in sales and marketing expenses. Our first quarter non-GAAP operating profit was $334 million or 31% of revenue. And as with the last quarter, more than 70% of this operating profit came from our Product business.
Our non-GAAP other income of $23 million included gains of $15 million related to the sale of certain assets and investments.
On the balance sheet, cash and short- and long-term marketable securities increased sequentially by $279 million to nearly $3.3 billion. Our first quarter cash flow from operations was $328 million, and our cash flow from investing yielded a positive $1 million, resulting in free cash flow of $329 million.
During Q1, we called our $75 million convertible, paying it off with cash, and we reduced our off-balance sheet equipment lease guarantees, ending Q1 with a balance of $931 million. 
I'll now turn to forward-looking commentary. Please note that non-GAAP to GAAP reconciliation tables for all applicable guidance are posted on our website.
Given our strong results in the first quarter, we are raising our guidance for 2010. Our broad channels and growing demand from the mobile market give us confidence to increase our full year revenue range to $4.5 billion to $4.8 billion. For the second quarter, we expect total revenue between $1.1 billion and $1.175 billion, which reflects tightness in supply for certain low capacity products.
Within this total Q2 revenue, we expect license and royalty revenue between $80 million and $90 million, slightly down sequentially since our second quarter royalty revenue reflects the seasonal first quarter revenue of our licensees.
For the full year, we are also raising our expectations for license and royalty revenue to a range of $350 million to $375 million.
Turning to gross margin, we expect the sequential improvement in cost to be less in Q2 than in Q1 due to anticipated higher mix of demand for certain products in our portfolio. We also expect our second quarter sales to reflect more promotional pricing in the retail channel associated with the moms, proms, dads and grads season.
We expect non-GAAP total gross margin for Q2 between 42% and 45% and non-GAAP product gross margin between 37% and 40%. For the full year 2010, we now anticipate that our cost reduction will be at the high end of the 30% to 40% range we provided in January, and we expect price reduction to be less than our previous estimates.
Partially offsetting these factors, we may utilize some non-captive supply in the second half of the year. We are raising our full year 2010 forecast for non-GAAP total gross margin to a range of 41% to 44% and for non-GAAP product gross margin to a range of 36% to 39%. For the 2010 total gross margin, this represents a more than five-percentage-point increase in the midpoint of the range from the previous guidance. 
Given our increased top line expectations for the year, we now expect non-GAAP operating expenses to be at the higher end of the range previously provided or approximately $750 million. For Q2, we forecast non-GAAP operating expenses of $180 million to $190 million. We now expect non-GAAP other income to be approximately $60 million for the year, and we forecast the non-GAAP tax rate to remain at approximately 37%.
We expect our 2010 capital investments to be at the higher end of the $700 million to $900 million range we previously provided and the estimated cash requirement for 2010 capital investments remains in the range of $300 million to $400 million concentrated later in the year.
In summary, we are pleased with our first quarter performance, and it is looking like 2010 will be a year in which we exceed the operating margin in our long-term financial model. We'll now open the call for your questions.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Couple questions, first of all, can you highlight a bit what the drivers are in sense in your OEM business here going forward. And how should we look at kind of the OEM segment as a percentage of your overall sales here in the next two, three quarters?
componenttext: Couple questions, first of all, can you highlight a bit what the drivers are in sense in your OEM business here going forward. And how should we look at kind of the OEM segment as a percentage of your overall sales here in the next two, three quarters?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The OEM business is growing. I mean we have said in the past that we believe we are the third largest supplier now and certainly in the top three suppliers of OEM Flash, and we believe that we have a tremendous room to grow. And we talked about very large
componenttext: The OEM business is growing. I mean we have said in the past that we believe we are the third largest supplier now and certainly in the top three suppliers of OEM Flash, and we believe that we have a tremendous room to grow. And we talked about very large, very broad front of design-ins [ph] particularly for embedded products, and we see that as really just starting. At the analyst day, We talked about AFM, that's the adopted flash management, which is part of our controller intelligence to allow us to optimize embedded flash to the specific applications of that platform, and we have seen very significant reception, positive reception for that. So I would say that we probably have moved now quite solidly from a model where maybe a year ago or a little bit more than that we were maybe 1/3 OEM and 2/3 retail to just the opposite, 1/3 retail and 2/3 OEM. And I don't -- I expect that this thing is going to be with us for the foreseeable future.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And the other question is in terms of kind of the e-book and tablet market and with your commentary that you're thinking of using some NAND-captive supply in the second half of the year, I mean how do you see those demand dynamics impacting the flash memo
componenttext: And the other question is in terms of kind of the e-book and tablet market and with your commentary that you're thinking of using some NAND-captive supply in the second half of the year, I mean how do you see those demand dynamics impacting the flash memory market and then, specifically, your usage of potentially moving to a little more non-captive?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The non-captive supply is very, very important in the long-term. And we've always said our model is to have 15% to 20% non-captive. However, it is also the case that with OEM becoming such a much stronger constituents. A portion of our output, I've said m
componenttext: The non-captive supply is very, very important in the long-term. And we've always said our model is to have 15% to 20% non-captive. However, it is also the case that with OEM becoming such a much stronger constituents. A portion of our output, I've said many times, that OEM really cannot be satisfied through non-captive because you have to quote several quarters out, and we really have to have control of our supplies. So that really will very likely, to the extent that we stay with this 2/3 OEM, 1/3 retail moving forward or around that, our ability to implore in non-captive will be reduced, and we will have to use more of captive supply.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And the tablet, e-book question?
componenttext: And the tablet, e-book question?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry, can you repeat the question on tablet?
componenttext: Sorry, can you repeat the question on tablet?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So basically, how do you see the tablet, e-book market impacting the NAND-flash industry here in 2010?
componenttext: So basically, how do you see the tablet, e-book market impacting the NAND-flash industry here in 2010?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tablets, to the extent that you define the iPAD as a tablet and its competitors being more or less the same, we view that as a very, very important new platform that drives the demand for flash, because it's really designed to be very thin, very long batt
componenttext: Tablets, to the extent that you define the iPAD as a tablet and its competitors being more or less the same, we view that as a very, very important new platform that drives the demand for flash, because it's really designed to be very thin, very long battery life and, therefore, really relies on attributes of flash for storage. The iPAD is driving 64 gigabytes. We fully expect that the competition will be really driving at the 64 gigabyte and opening up to 128 and 260 gigabyte. This is very, very positive development for the NAND-industry, no matter who serves it, and also very important because, again, the analyst day, we talked about thin is in. What thin means, when you have very thin product and you can't have a fan to cool the environment, you basically are driven to use modular flash, modular SSD, which is SSD functionality but not necessarily in the 1.8-inch or 2.5-inch form factors, [ph] and that clearly plays to our strength because we have the ability to customize solid state disks to be basically -- to fit into very, very thin in any kind of a profile, which, of course, no disk drives can do. So in that kind of environment, people are starting to look at SSD not just, is it lower -- does it match the cost of hard disk drive but more is it an enabling technology that allows that kind of full function.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Kate Kotlarsky for Jim Covello. Eli, I had a quick question on the comments you made about, is supply and demand being tight in general in 2010. I was just curious if you kind of look at the second half versus the first half, how much tighter if a
componenttext: This is Kate Kotlarsky for Jim Covello. Eli, I had a quick question on the comments you made about, is supply and demand being tight in general in 2010. I was just curious if you kind of look at the second half versus the first half, how much tighter if at all do you think the second half of the year is going to be? And then kind of tying into that into your comments about evaluating Toshiba, kind of what are the things that you're going to be looking at as you think about potentially making the investment in Fab 5?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so there's a number of questions in there. So let me try and address those, and I'm sure there'll be maybe a few other questions on that.Judy has indicated we are raising our guidance for the year from $4 billion to $4.4 billion to $4.5 billion to
componenttext:
Okay, so there's a number of questions in there. So let me try and address those, and I'm sure there'll be maybe a few other questions on that.
Judy has indicated we are raising our guidance for the year from $4 billion to $4.4 billion to $4.5 billion to $4.8 billion. That's $500 million additional revenues, which, of course, would require best potential [ph] additional gigabytes, petabytes in units that we are forecasting we will need flash for this year. So, of course, the solution to getting this supply is from, first from captive, which is Fab 4, and then non-captive. And then anything we do with Fab 5 will definitely not have any impact. It will not be available until well into 2011 at the earliest. So this is what, in my remarks, I said we are striving to get our output this year to about 75% more bits this year later in the year. And this comes from primarily greater efficiency in Fab 4, better yields than we had expected in Fab 4 as much utilization as X3 as we can squeeze out of wafers, [ph] and that's going very well and building some additional capacity in Fab 4 in the cleaning space. And there we are somewhat limited by equipment lead times and, of course, there's not much space left in there. So all of these in combination give you that 75% or so increase, and that may not be enough, and in that case, we will explore the non-captive option.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So that 75% implies that you're primarily using captive supply and not too much non-captive?
componenttext: So that 75% implies that you're primarily using captive supply and not too much non-captive?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct, yes.
componenttext: That's correct, yes.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The 75% is the amount by which we believe we can grow our captive output in 2010. Revenue in bits could potentially be more if we purchase non-captive and/or we're able to increase our inventory turns.
componenttext: The 75% is the amount by which we believe we can grow our captive output in 2010. Revenue in bits could potentially be more if we purchase non-captive and/or we're able to increase our inventory turns.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That 75%, how does that compare to what you would expect for the industry in general?
componenttext: That 75%, how does that compare to what you would expect for the industry in general?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So we've said in the past, that we think from what we see from various independent marketing, from -- they're projecting between 70% and 90% bit increase, and we've said at the beginning of the year that we are going to be unable to -- that we'll be up to
componenttext: So we've said in the past, that we think from what we see from various independent marketing, from -- they're projecting between 70% and 90% bit increase, and we've said at the beginning of the year that we are going to be unable to -- that we'll be up to 70%. Now we are more confident that we can be at about 75%, still at the low end of that industry range.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Paul Coster with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Paul Coster with JP Morgan.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As you approach the CapEx decision along with your partner Toshiba, can you just talk to us a little bit about what's going into those discussions. And also, is there any chance that you may again revise the nature of the joint venture and the share of th
componenttext: As you approach the CapEx decision along with your partner Toshiba, can you just talk to us a little bit about what's going into those discussions. And also, is there any chance that you may again revise the nature of the joint venture and the share of the JV that you own?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, Paul, we announced more than two years ago an MOU with Toshiba and a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Toshiba for the creation of Fab 5, and that, of course, ran into the recession of the whole industry and really was put us
componenttext: Well, as you know, Paul, we announced more than two years ago an MOU with Toshiba and a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Toshiba for the creation of Fab 5, and that, of course, ran into the recession of the whole industry and really was put us on hold. About a month ago, Toshiba announced that they will commence the construction of the shell in Yokkaichi. This is basically a decision to build a, just a building. And we certainly plan to continue the partnership that we have with Toshiba in Fab 5. However, I have also said in the past and we really feel very strongly that we need to play our part as best we can to maintain health in the industry by not bringing our new capacity, any new capacity that we have from any new sources too soon to the market. That would be not good for us, and, of course, we can't control what our competitors are doing. But basically, this, for the last, I term [ph] last quarter as curbing our enthusiasm. That said, we do see demand for flash growing at a very strong pace both from the mobile and from other markets, including SSD. And therefore, we do -- again, I've said on February 26, it's not a question of if we're going to participate in Fab 5 but when and to what extent and the timing and so on. All of those have not yet been decided, and we will let you know when decisions are being made.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think that Toshiba shares your philosophy at the moment regarding being cautious about the introduction of new capacity?
componenttext: Do you think that Toshiba shares your philosophy at the moment regarding being cautious about the introduction of new capacity?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I suggest you ask Toshiba that [ph].
componenttext: I suggest you ask Toshiba that [ph].

componenttext: Our next question will come from Bobby Gujavarty with Deutsche Bank.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I just had a question given how strong OEM sales have been. Do you get any sense or has this entered into your discussion in terms of maybe OEM pre-buying in anticipation of a shortage in the back half of the year? Have you kind of made some assumptions f
componenttext: I just had a question given how strong OEM sales have been. Do you get any sense or has this entered into your discussion in terms of maybe OEM pre-buying in anticipation of a shortage in the back half of the year? Have you kind of made some assumptions for that? Have you cleaned your backlog so to speak just to account for any possibility of pull-in of orders?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer it without -- indirectly. We do feel that -- you've heard me say or us say that in the next decade, we think that flash will be bigger than you think, and that's really based on the mobile, the way it's going, as well as the solid state. The
componenttext: Let me answer it without -- indirectly. We do feel that -- you've heard me say or us say that in the next decade, we think that flash will be bigger than you think, and that's really based on the mobile, the way it's going, as well as the solid state. There's two major new markets that are very, very early. So the industry really need to build additional capacity that doesn't exist. I think we all know that. And the key is really the timing of those because the return investment by itself is tied to the timing. Now, what that leads me to say is that over the next several years, there will be periods, I believe, of shortages of flash memory. And that will be times where people will understand OEMs, particularly large OEMs, that flash is becoming very strategic to their business. You can view it as a commodity. But when you can't get it at any price because it's just not there because your demand far exceeds the available capacity of the industry and the cumulative demand of all customers, then, of course, people will start wanting to secure for themselves some of that capacity. So I do expect that some of that may happen. Of course, we don't know for a fact, but I would not be surprised if the strategic nature in the next few years is going to start becoming effective. It's no secret. Flash is a very, very tough technology. There are very few companies that can really deliver leading-edge technology and very high volume both from the technology and the manufacturing and the balance sheet. So the answer to your question is yes, I think there's going to be some of that. Some OEMs will start taking steps to assure themselves of supply.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, this is Judy. I'll just add that at present time, we work very closely with our customers, and we monitor both the retail channel inventory and the OEM channel inventory, and we believe that both are at normal levels today.
componenttext: Bob, this is Judy. I'll just add that at present time, we work very closely with our customers, and we monitor both the retail channel inventory and the OEM channel inventory, and we believe that both are at normal levels today.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I know we've had some good positive retail sales data out of the U.S. Is there -- are you at all more hopeful maybe now than three months ago, or any color on the retail side of the business? Not suggesting you give us the December prediction, but is ther
componenttext: I know we've had some good positive retail sales data out of the U.S. Is there -- are you at all more hopeful maybe now than three months ago, or any color on the retail side of the business? Not suggesting you give us the December prediction, but is there any inkling of hope there on that side?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I mean, I think that the U.S. retail and Europe retail depends very much on the recovery in the economy. And to the extent that people are beginning to be a lot more optimistic about return of growth, even a slow growth will be very helpf
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I mean, I think that the U.S. retail and Europe retail depends very much on the recovery in the economy. And to the extent that people are beginning to be a lot more optimistic about return of growth, even a slow growth will be very helpful.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Uche Orji with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Uche Orji with UBS.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just ask you about your confidence at getting access [ph] to non-captive supply. So right now, demand supply's in balance like you mentioned. But is there any way you are feeling more assured at being able to tap non-captive supply? And are these a
componenttext: Let me just ask you about your confidence at getting access [ph] to non-captive supply. So right now, demand supply's in balance like you mentioned. But is there any way you are feeling more assured at being able to tap non-captive supply? And are these already at pre-negotiated prices? Or will you be spending on what the spot market is doing in terms of your future dependence on non-captive?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have legal document, legal agreements that afford us guaranteed access to capacity from several of our licensees. However, again, I've said in the past that you just can't turn if off on a switch. You can't just come and say, okay, next week ship me th
componenttext: We have legal document, legal agreements that afford us guaranteed access to capacity from several of our licensees. However, again, I've said in the past that you just can't turn if off on a switch. You can't just come and say, okay, next week ship me this -- there is a forecasting period, there's lead times, and it's not something you can just jump in and out of. So it's not that easy. There's a lead time involved.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You were talking about some low capacity NAND that you're citing as being popular. Are these in retail or in OEMs? And if in OEMs, what kind of products are using this lower capacity NAND?
componenttext: You were talking about some low capacity NAND that you're citing as being popular. Are these in retail or in OEMs? And if in OEMs, what kind of products are using this lower capacity NAND?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So I think the main driver for low capacity cards, mostly microSD one or two gigabyte, amazingly, I said it's really amazingly, there's a huge number of handsets in countries such as China, India, South America and so on, in Africa, where you can get a ve
componenttext: So I think the main driver for low capacity cards, mostly microSD one or two gigabyte, amazingly, I said it's really amazingly, there's a huge number of handsets in countries such as China, India, South America and so on, in Africa, where you can get a very good handset for $20 to $25. And those ones used to rely almost entirely on embedded flash, mostly NOR flash or low capacity NAND flash. And just in the last several quarters, they seem to have switched in very large qualities to cards like microSD in one or two gigabytes, and they can play music, and they can actually, they have a FM radio. So they become now, the music player, and some of them for $25, you have a camera. So we traditionally, we expected the one gigabyte and two gigabyte even, to kind of disappear, but it has come back because of this phenomena. We think it's here to stay for a long time.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: How much of your bit production in Q1 was at 24-nanometers? And within the 24-nanometers, when will the X3 or X4 be qualified and enter full production?
componenttext: How much of your bit production in Q1 was at 24-nanometers? And within the 24-nanometers, when will the X3 or X4 be qualified and enter full production?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have said the 24-nanometer is in development right now, in advanced development, and that we expect to start production by late this year.
componenttext: We have said the 24-nanometer is in development right now, in advanced development, and that we expect to start production by late this year.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Is there any cost difference in terms of a CapEx cost to add capacity say 10,000 wafers demands incremental capacity at 24. How does that compare with the previous generation if at all? Just for us to have a sense of what this means for you from a CapEx a
componenttext: Is there any cost difference in terms of a CapEx cost to add capacity say 10,000 wafers demands incremental capacity at 24. How does that compare with the previous generation if at all? Just for us to have a sense of what this means for you from a CapEx and cash flow standpoint.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Every generation of technology migration does require CapEx investments usually to a far lesser degree than starting just wafers from some scratch. And it depends what kind of -- different companies have different transitions between technology. In our ca
componenttext: Every generation of technology migration does require CapEx investments usually to a far lesser degree than starting just wafers from some scratch. And it depends what kind of -- different companies have different transitions between technology. In our case, the technology -- I would say 2-nanometer technology and our 24-nanometer technology require relatively small equipment changes. So that's actually very positive.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Craig Ellis with Caris & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Ellis with Caris & Company.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is on just your cost reduction. Can you help us understand the linearity of the cost reduction that you had hoped to achieve this year, more front-end loaded, relatively balanced? Is there anything that would cause it to be lumpy throug
componenttext: The first question is on just your cost reduction. Can you help us understand the linearity of the cost reduction that you had hoped to achieve this year, more front-end loaded, relatively balanced? Is there anything that would cause it to be lumpy through the year?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, I would say that given how much of the cost reduction we were able to pull in to the first quarter, that in terms of sequential improvement in cost per bit, I expect that Q1 may be a quarter that is difficult to repeat. But relative to the other qu
componenttext: Craig, I would say that given how much of the cost reduction we were able to pull in to the first quarter, that in terms of sequential improvement in cost per bit, I expect that Q1 may be a quarter that is difficult to repeat. But relative to the other quarters, I don't necessarily expect much difference between the Q2, Q3, Q4 in the approximate level of cost decline. And as I said, we expect the full year to reach a cost improvement at the high-end of our range of 30% to 40%.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Judy, just on the outlook for the year, it looks like there is an unusual degree of stability in revenues from the first half to the back half. Does that reflect concern about the strength of the Retail business in the back half of the year? Does that ref
componenttext: Judy, just on the outlook for the year, it looks like there is an unusual degree of stability in revenues from the first half to the back half. Does that reflect concern about the strength of the Retail business in the back half of the year? Does that reflect concern about supply availability beyond your captive bit growth? How do we interpret the implication for second half growth off of the full year guidance?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: It does reflect some potential shortage of supply, particularly for the low capacity product that we just discussed a few minutes ago, the one- and two-gigabyte memory. And at the moment, as we indicated, the Retail business does remain somewhat soft in t
componenttext: It does reflect some potential shortage of supply, particularly for the low capacity product that we just discussed a few minutes ago, the one- and two-gigabyte memory. And at the moment, as we indicated, the Retail business does remain somewhat soft in the U.S. and Europe. And we are optimistic that we'll begin to see some improvement later in the year, but we haven't seen that yet.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Kevin Cassidy with Thomas Weisel Partners.
componenttext: Next question comes from Kevin Cassidy with Thomas Weisel Partners.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not going to give a specific, mix but our 3-bit-per-cell was above 50% in the first quarter, and we expect it to remain approximately 50% or a bit more for the entire year.
componenttext: We're not going to give a specific, mix but our 3-bit-per-cell was above 50% in the first quarter, and we expect it to remain approximately 50% or a bit more for the entire year.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we are 32-nanometer and some of our competitors [ph] are 34-nanometer. Actually, it's funny because people are talking about -- throwing numbers about what is 2x. Now we have 20-nanometer class, which means whatever you want -- it has a two in s
componenttext: Actually, we are 32-nanometer and some of our competitors [ph] are 34-nanometer. Actually, it's funny because people are talking about -- throwing numbers about what is 2x. Now we have 20-nanometer class, which means whatever you want -- it has a two in somewhere in the number. Anyway, from 32-nanometer -- first of all 32-nanometer from 43-nanometer is a very substantial cost reduction. And particularly, if you stay 3-bits to 3-bits 43-nanometer X3 or 32-nanometer X3. As we get to lower geometries, more scaled, I'm sure -- again I've said before, we expect that the difficulty of implementing X3 will increase. But we feel that they will be playing to our strengths. [ph] So we fully expect that when we go to 24-nanometer, we will be able to take our X3 with us without in any way a compromising performance. So from 32 to 24, again, a pretty substantial cost reduction. And basically, you're looking at -- we've said NAND is going to start slowing down, and we truly believe that. But at the same time, the industry and we are moving still at a pretty rapid pace, and I would say the end of scaling of NAND has probably been greatly exaggerated, maybe by us as well. So actually, it's looking a little bit better all the time, and that, of course, would very good news for SSD particularly.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Daniel Berenbaum with Auriga USA.
componenttext: Next question will come from Daniel Berenbaum with Auriga USA.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First question, what is the progress on getting 3-bit-per-cell into OEM? I know there had been some reliability concerns as you move to 3-bit-per-cell. How much are you selling into OEM currently? And are you going to be able to expand that?
componenttext: First question, what is the progress on getting 3-bit-per-cell into OEM? I know there had been some reliability concerns as you move to 3-bit-per-cell. How much are you selling into OEM currently? And are you going to be able to expand that?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Initially, it has been an uphill battle, but it's getting much better now because we have been able to demonstrate two very exhaustive OEM qualifications that the product is very, very good. And furthermore, through this AFM adaptable flash memory, we can
componenttext: Initially, it has been an uphill battle, but it's getting much better now because we have been able to demonstrate two very exhaustive OEM qualifications that the product is very, very good. And furthermore, through this AFM adaptable flash memory, we can actually get very, very, very, good performance with X3 and everybody understands that, the cost benefits of that. So I would say that the efforts of the last year have -- are beginning to bear fruits right now. And I think that once we are over the hump that people will whole scale [ph] adopt X3.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I should have said embedded actually.
componenttext: I'm sorry, I should have said embedded actually.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm talking about embedded. It's removable, there's -- I mean cards we've been shipping -- in cards we are the ones that qualify X3 and clearly that moves into production very early.
componenttext: Yes, I'm talking about embedded. It's removable, there's -- I mean cards we've been shipping -- in cards we are the ones that qualify X3 and clearly that moves into production very early.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So then that progress on X3, does that change your long-term view on what you could do for cost-per-bit reduction? Does that improve that longer term view? And then related to that, Judy, you'd said that you expect operating margin this year to be above t
componenttext: So then that progress on X3, does that change your long-term view on what you could do for cost-per-bit reduction? Does that improve that longer term view? And then related to that, Judy, you'd said that you expect operating margin this year to be above the long-term business model. Yous had a very strong quarter. Why does this quarter not change your view of what the long-term business model should be? Can you just help me understand why you're -- how you're thinking about that?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me start with the second part of your question. At our analyst day at the end of February, when I laid out the long-term financial model, I described that model as a model that we believe is optimal [Indiscernible] over the long-term in order to
componenttext: Yes. Let me start with the second part of your question. At our analyst day at the end of February, when I laid out the long-term financial model, I described that model as a model that we believe is optimal [Indiscernible] over the long-term in order to balance growth and profits and cash flow. I said that in some years, we expect that we will beat the long-term financial model and in some years, we will miss it. So it's not my expectation to continue to adjust that long-term financial model but rather aim for that over time. And what I'm saying is it looks like this year is a year where we can beat the long-term financial model. And I'm sorry, what was the first part of your question?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the good progress on getting 3-bit-per-cell into embedded. Does that change your view of the longer term cost reduction? I think you talked about, longer term cost reduction as 20% to 30% per bit annually. Does the improved adoption of 3-bit-per-c
componenttext: Just on the good progress on getting 3-bit-per-cell into embedded. Does that change your view of the longer term cost reduction? I think you talked about, longer term cost reduction as 20% to 30% per bit annually. Does the improved adoption of 3-bit-per-cell into embedded change the view of that?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, because we assumed it in the first place. We of course, assumed success not -- so we are marching to our plan, and we are doing well against our plan.
componenttext: No, because we assumed it in the first place. We of course, assumed success not -- so we are marching to our plan, and we are doing well against our plan.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Hendi Susanto with Gabelli.
componenttext: Next question will come from Hendi Susanto with Gabelli.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First, I would like to understand more about your plan with regards to the non-captive supply. Like, how much confidence do you have in securing 10% to 15% of the, coming from the non-captive supply? And how much is the maximum, like non-captive supply ca
componenttext: First, I would like to understand more about your plan with regards to the non-captive supply. Like, how much confidence do you have in securing 10% to 15% of the, coming from the non-captive supply? And how much is the maximum, like non-captive supply can you get in the second half of 2010? Meaning that whether you will be able to secure more than the 10% to 15% that you mentioned before? And could you help us understand and quantify what gross margin impact of using non-captive supply?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me clarify, we've not given any percentage of non-captive for the second half of this year. And when Eli was describing a 10% or 15%, he was saying that, that is sort of the range that we think we might be in, in some periods of time over time. I expe
componenttext: Let me clarify, we've not given any percentage of non-captive for the second half of this year. And when Eli was describing a 10% or 15%, he was saying that, that is sort of the range that we think we might be in, in some periods of time over time. I expect that if we use non-captive in the second half of this year, it will probably be modest amounts of non-captive. But it is one factor that we are taking into account in our expectations of gross margins for the second half.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And the second margin implication. The margin implications, as we've said before, of course, that this is much lower margin business.
componenttext: And the second margin implication. The margin implications, as we've said before, of course, that this is much lower margin business.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you mentioned that for OEM business, there's a need of using more captive supply. And how about solid state disk drive? Will the choice of non-captive versus captive supply matter in SSD?
componenttext: And then you mentioned that for OEM business, there's a need of using more captive supply. And how about solid state disk drive? Will the choice of non-captive versus captive supply matter in SSD?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, very much so. Certainly, a big part of the SSD market will be OEM, very much so in OEM. There will, of course, be the retail space. In retail, it can be non-captive. But I have to say that for SSD, we have a very substantial engineering effort, and I
componenttext: Yes, very much so. Certainly, a big part of the SSD market will be OEM, very much so in OEM. There will, of course, be the retail space. In retail, it can be non-captive. But I have to say that for SSD, we have a very substantial engineering effort, and I could tell you that it's very, very, very focused on squeezing out the best performance from the flash that we know best, which is our own captive flash. So it's very difficult -- to get the kind of performance that we feel we can deliver in an SSD environment at the low-cost, very high performance and great reliability, we feel that the best approach there is to use captive for that, even for retail.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: For the low capacity memory product, how is the margin compared to your corporate average margin? Is it lower or is comparable or higher?
componenttext: For the low capacity memory product, how is the margin compared to your corporate average margin? Is it lower or is comparable or higher?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Margin is very good. And, just as an aside, we have said that the new channels that we have today that we didn't have a year ago really has given us the diversification to allow us to make decisions of how we allocate our supply between these markets base
componenttext: Margin is very good. And, just as an aside, we have said that the new channels that we have today that we didn't have a year ago really has given us the diversification to allow us to make decisions of how we allocate our supply between these markets based on maximizing profitability.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Eli, I was wondering if you could help us understand in regards to the new channels. Of that $626 million in revenue that you did in the OEM, how much of that came from the new channel?
componenttext: Eli, I was wondering if you could help us understand in regards to the new channels. Of that $626 million in revenue that you did in the OEM, how much of that came from the new channel?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Betsy, we're not going to break out the specific mix of old channels versus new channels. But I will say that our business from new channels and new customers that we added in 2009 did grow sequentially from Q4 to Q1.
componenttext: Betsy, we're not going to break out the specific mix of old channels versus new channels. But I will say that our business from new channels and new customers that we added in 2009 did grow sequentially from Q4 to Q1.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And it is quite substantial.
componenttext: And it is quite substantial.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And it is quite substantial in terms of the growth or the percent of the overall?
componenttext: And it is quite substantial in terms of the growth or the percent of the overall?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Both. Well, the percentage for sure.
componenttext: Both. Well, the percentage for sure.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Percentage, yes. But it did grow. As I said, our OEM revenue in total was down sequentially 2%, although keep in mind that was going from a 14-week quarter to a 13-week quarter. But regardless, the new channels and new customers grew sequentially from Q4
componenttext: Percentage, yes. But it did grow. As I said, our OEM revenue in total was down sequentially 2%, although keep in mind that was going from a 14-week quarter to a 13-week quarter. But regardless, the new channels and new customers grew sequentially from Q4 to Q1.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As we look at the back half of the year and the concerns that you seem to be highlighting about capacity constraints and supply, what's that going to do to your new channels and your new relationships as you're looking at trying to allocate the supply tha
componenttext: As we look at the back half of the year and the concerns that you seem to be highlighting about capacity constraints and supply, what's that going to do to your new channels and your new relationships as you're looking at trying to allocate the supply that you're going to have to your various new businesses?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are looking at all of these channels as strategic and long-term. And we understand that to do so, if we have to get into allocation, we have to do so in a very sensible way and to spread the pain, if you will. But our number one priority, frankly
componenttext: Well, we are looking at all of these channels as strategic and long-term. And we understand that to do so, if we have to get into allocation, we have to do so in a very sensible way and to spread the pain, if you will. But our number one priority, frankly, is to see what we can do on the supply side, so that we don't constrain our customers.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from Tristan Gerra with Robert Baird.
componenttext: Next question will come from Tristan Gerra with Robert Baird.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: What were your channel inventories at the end of Q1 for flash cards? I think you were at around five weeks last quarter?
componenttext: What were your channel inventories at the end of Q1 for flash cards? I think you were at around five weeks last quarter?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our retail channel inventory on a worldwide basis is at about seven-and-a-half weeks on a backward looking basis at the end of Q1, and that's very similar to what it was at the end of Q1 last year. It's a very normal range. It tends to be lower at the end
componenttext: Our retail channel inventory on a worldwide basis is at about seven-and-a-half weeks on a backward looking basis at the end of Q1, and that's very similar to what it was at the end of Q1 last year. It's a very normal range. It tends to be lower at the end of Q4 on a backward-looking basis because of the very strong sell-through in the December timeframe.

componenttext: Our last question will come from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: Quick clarification, Judy, the full year gross margin guidance assumes non-captive supply buying in second half this year?
