headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the SanDisk Corporation's Fiscal Third Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jay Iyer, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the SanDisk Corporation's Fiscal Third Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jay Iyer, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Elizabeth, and good afternoon. Joining us on the call today are Dr. Eli Harari, Chairman and CEO of SanDisk; Sanjay Mehrotra, President and COO; and Judy Bruner, Executive Vice President of Administration and CFO.Before we begin, please note
componenttext:
Thank you, Elizabeth, and good afternoon. Joining us on the call today are Dr. Eli Harari, Chairman and CEO of SanDisk; Sanjay Mehrotra, President and COO; and Judy Bruner, Executive Vice President of Administration and CFO.
Before we begin, please note that any non-GAAP financial measures discussed during this call as defined by the SEC in Regulation G will be reconciled to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure. That reconciliation is now available along with supplemental schedules on our website at sandisk.com/ir. 
In addition, during our call today, we will make forward-looking statements. Any statement that refers to expectations, projections or other characterizations of future events, including financial projections and future market conditions, is a forward-looking statement. 
Actual results may materially differ from those expressed in these forward-looking statements. For more information, please refer to the risk factors discussed in the documents we filed from time to time with the SEC, including our annual report on Form 10-K for fiscal 2009 and our subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. 
SanDisk assumes no obligation to update these forward-looking statements, which speak as of to date hereof. With that, I will turn the call over to Eli.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and good afternoon, everyone. This is the last quarterly call that I will address here as SanDisk Chairman and CEO. Therefore, rather than discussing our business in the third and fourth quarter, allow me to take this opportunity to review
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and good afternoon, everyone. This is the last quarterly call that I will address here as SanDisk Chairman and CEO. Therefore, rather than discussing our business in the third and fourth quarter, allow me to take this opportunity to review our most recent past and where I see our opportunities and challenges in the coming years.
Sanjay and Judy will discuss our Q3 results and our expectations for Q4. In the past three years, we experienced the industry's most severe downturn followed by strong recovery. We experienced six consecutive weak quarters generating a substantial operating loss followed by six consecutive quarters of remarkable recovery. 
The current recovery continues even in the face of adverse macroeconomic conditions in the U.S., much of Europe and Japan. For SanDisk, our cumulative non-GAAP operating profit for the six quarters ending this year will be more than 2.5x greater than the cumulative non-GAAP operating loss in the preceding six quarters. 
We believe our industry is driven by several powerful secular trends that point to sustainable profitable growth for us in the coming years. First, in the more developed economies, growth for us continues to be driven by the phenomenal rise of the mobile Internet and social networks that fueled a surging demand for mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets, that in turn drive strong demand for flash memory. 
The second major secular force is the surging consumer middle-class in emerging countries such as China, India, Latin America, Middle East and Africa. We are directing substantial resources to expand our businesses in these emerging countries and in the coming years, we are encouraged by our gains to date.
The past downturn has taught the industry that even relatively small in balances, either up or down, between the managed supply and disproportionately amplify market volatility. I have often said that the non-industry is self-correcting and in the current recovery, the industry did an excellent job of adjusting to compensate for the excessive capital investments that were made in the 2005 through 2008 timeframe. 
Industry cycles, are a fact of life in our business and even severe downturns are in fact, quite manageable provided you have a solid balance sheet, competitive technology and manufacturing base and diversified sales channels so that you're not overly reliant on any single channel or any single local economy. 
New found capacity decisions are made 18 months ahead of production and even on the best laid plans, it's not easy to achieve and maintain a healthy balance. Some products such as the iPhone, the iPad and the Kindle come out of nowhere and very quickly enter hockey-stick growth trajectory that creates a whole new market category, while other products such solid state drives, SSD, can take much longer to develop. Our focus in SanDisk has been, and will continue to be, long-term value creation, where we do our best to balance growth with profitability and cash flow.
Turning now to flash technology. Non-flash has confounded many skeptics as it marches with confidence to mass production at the 24 through 27-nanometer technology node a fact that seemed iffy to many just two years ago. An important element in the success of this rapid scaling has been the all but mandatory adoption of managed NAND, requiring sophisticated controllers to compensate for deteriorating raw NAND reliability and performance. This is amply demonstrated for 3-bits-per-cell, X3 NAND, where the market is witnessing a wide variability in performance and reliability between the X3 product from different NAND suppliers. 
I believe that SanDisk is uniquely well-positioned in this space because from day one, we stayed true to delivering system flash and managed non-solutions, and this is our third generation X3 in production, where we have optimized our chip designs and perfected our controllers to deliver a solid solution. 
We now expect NAND to scale down to below 20 nanometers in the next few years. This will likely be achieved with existing lithography tools running in existing and new advanced non-fab and this bodes well for our Yokkaichi fabs as they become more fully depreciated in the coming years. 
As we push the roadmap even further, extreme ultraviolet, UV lithography tools will become indispensable and I expect the transition to UV to be spread over a number of years and to be quite challenging for the industry. With regards to post non-technology alternatives, I remain optimistic about our three-dimensional 3D read/writes diode rates, currently under development with our partner Toshiba. As I've said previously, I expect highly skilled NAND and post-NAND technology to happily coexist over the next decade.
Moving to IT. Our flash memory and system portfolio and know-how are now dominated by many strong second-generation patents. These patents cover managed NAND, multi-bits NAND, advanced NAND device, process and memory chip design patents, solid state disk, secure portable content, strong air correcting algorithms, high-speed flash caching, wear out optimization, application Adaptive storage, 3D memories and so on. We believe this IP will provide us substantial leverage in the years ahead.
Turning now to our target markets. We have previously spoken about the legacy consumer markets, the mobile market and computing, including SSD and cloud storage. Of these, we believe that mobile continues to present us the greatest opportunities in the coming years. The more than 1.2 billion handsets that will be sold this year drove any other consumer or computing market. Increasingly, these are smartphones and tablets, which are morphing into sophisticated portable PCs that are always connected and that increasingly require more flash storage to support the explosion in third-party mobile apps and user content. 
Handsets are also rapidly assuming the role of the ultimate portable convergence device first with music and cameras then with video games, video capture, GPS and apps. As for SSD, these are transforming Enterprise Storage as we speak and we are within one or two generations from their mass adoption in notebook PCs and other sim clients. 
To be a market leader in SSD, you need to have access to leading-edge, high-quality flash, shippable in high volumes at a competitive cost, applying sophisticated know how for managing highly skilled NAND, having the recorded patents and building on strong OEM credentials. SanDisk has it all and we are working diligently to gain leadership position in this space. 
As for our balance sheet, the numbers speaks for themselves and I believe that SanDisk is exceptionally well-equipped to execute our long term global growth strategy. Last but not the least, our people. SanDisk people, the "Can Do" team, driven by passion for innovation with a consistent track record of flawless execution through good and bad times. 
SanDisk technologists and engineers retain the deep technology DNA from our early days. Under Sanjay's leadership, I believe SanDisk will continue to grow and prosper in the coming years. The management transition is going well and I expect 2011 will be another strong year for SanDisk. I will now pass it on to Sanjay.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eli and good afternoon, everyone. As expected, the mobile market remains the key driver of the company's revenue in the third quarter and it represented half of our total quarter's revenue mix. Our top five customers in the third quarter were a
componenttext:
Thank you, Eli and good afternoon, everyone. As expected, the mobile market remains the key driver of the company's revenue in the third quarter and it represented half of our total quarter's revenue mix. Our top five customers in the third quarter were all in the mobile phone end market. We are particularly pleased with the strong growth of our embedded products business during the quarter. 
With an increasing number of handsets with our iNANDs for embedded storage going into production, iNAND units sold increased by more than 100% from Q2 levels. Our embedded products, including iNANDs, made up nearly 30% of our OEM revenues, up from just under 20% in Q2. 
Furthermore, strong focus on customer qualification and adoption of our FC-based iNAND products are starting to pay off and certain handsets with FCI NAND embedded are now starting production. Our iNAND product line is also starting to generate design wins in numerous tablet SKUs, and we are excited to be part of this rapidly evolving new category. 
Additionally, in the third quarter, we had a successful launch of our embedded solid state dryer, the iSSD with capacity ranging from four to 64 gigabytes and it has a generated a high level of interest from both the PC and non-PC OEMs. We expect this product category to grow in 2011 and beyond.
Retail delivered a solid quarter as total unit sales grew at a healthy double-digit rate on a year-over-year and sequential basis with the average capacity of retail units sold approaching five gigabytes. In North America, we saw the anticipated seasonal lift in USB flash drive sales, primarily driven by the back-to-school season. 
We also saw healthy double-digit revenue growth from the BRIC regions both on a sequential and year-over-year basis. In Europe, despite weak consumer sentiment, our sales grew nicely and we believe increases in channel penetration and strong brand preference are leading to market share gains there.
From an operational standpoint, our fabs completed the transition to 32-nanometer technology. Our high mix of 32-nanometer FC technology in the third quarter enabled us to deliver record product gross margins. We expect to begin volume production of both X2 and X3 memory architectures on our 24-nanometer technology in the fourth quarter. 
I would like to make a few comments about the pricing environment. Industry pricing trends began to soften in the second half of Q3 in certain segments. We believe that this is primarily due to pockets of demand, supply imbalances caused by low grade TLC, meaning competitor's three level cell NAND and early production of 2x nanometer products from other suppliers that are not qualified by large OEMs. 
We believe that this low grade pricing impacted certain parts of our OEM business, specifically white label cards and wafers, while we choose not to compete at some of these prices with our high-quality X3. A brief update on fab capacity. The final phase of fab four expansion is underway and we expect the facility to attain its full capacity in mid-2011. Regarding Fab 5, we continue to proceed with caution and have not made the final decision regarding the NAND start date or the days of expansion. 
To summarize, we are very pleased with our third quarter execution and performance. The fundamental growth drivers for NAND flash remain firmly in place and I look forward to providing you an update on our fourth quarter results and future outlook early next year. I will now hand the call over to Judy.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sanjay. With third quarter revenue growth of 32% year-over-year and operating margins of 35% on a GAAP basis and 37% non-GAAP, I believe our performance stands out even within a favorable NAND industry environment. Our revenue of $1.234 billi
componenttext:
Thank you, Sanjay. With third quarter revenue growth of 32% year-over-year and operating margins of 35% on a GAAP basis and 37% non-GAAP, I believe our performance stands out even within a favorable NAND industry environment. 
Our revenue of $1.234 billion within the higher end of the range we predicted in July with both product revenue and license and royalty revenue coming in as expected. Our product revenue for the third quarter shifted a bit toward retail with a mix of 62% OEM and 38% retail. Our ASP per gigabyte declined a modest 5% with our prices mostly firm through August and some price reductions in September. 
Our Q3 gigabyte sold grew 8% sequentially and 71% year-over-year. And on a year-to-date basis, our gigabyte sold have grown 84%. In Q3, we experienced solid retail growth both sequentially and year-over-year in Americas, Europe and Asia, with overall retail revenue of 13% sequentially and 20% year-over-year. Our retail channels delivered sequential unit and revenue growth in all key end markets including mobile, imaging, USB, audio video and gaming with the strongest retail growth coming from USB for back-to-school and for mobile products. 
Our OEM revenue was flat sequentially and up 55% year-over-year. On a sequential basis, OEM revenue did grow for mobile products but was offset by a reduction in other product categories primarily white label cards and wafers. Across all channels, our third quarter revenue by end market came 50% from the mobile market, 22% up from imaging, 10% from USB's, 10% from other product markets and 8% from license and royalty revenue. 
Our product gross margins increased six percentage points sequentially to 48%, our highest ever product gross margin. With our product cost per gigabyte improving 13% sequentially compared to only a 5% price decline. Our cost decline was stronger than expected, due primarily to higher 32-nanometer yields and rapid transition to 32-nanometer X3. X3 memory continued to account for more than half of our shipments and non-captive memory was used for only 1% of our shipments. 
Non-GAAP operating expenses grew $13 million sequentially with the growth predominantly in R&D. Sales and marketing expenses were down slightly sequentially as certain expenses we had anticipated in Q3 moved to Q4. Our non-GAAP other income of $15 million included gains of $8 million related to foreign exchange and the sale of certain investments. Our expected non-GAAP tax rate for the year has come down to 35% and this reduced rate combined the certain onetime items resulted in a third quarter non-GAAP tax rate of approximately 34%.
On the balance sheet, cash and short and long term marketable securities increased sequentially by $1.3 billion to over $5 billion. Deducting the maturity value of our convertible debt securities, our net cash is a record $2.9 billion. Cash increases during Q3 included $878 million from our convertible debt financing, $379 million of cash flow from operations, $60 million of excess cash returned from the Flash Partners joint venture and $23 million from employee options and the employee Stock purchase plan. We utilized $22 million of cash for non-fab capital purchases. 
Free cash flow for Q3 was $416 million, bringing the year-to-date free cash flow to over $1.1 billion. SanDisk's portion of Fab 3 and Fab 4 investments on a year-to-date basis has been approximately $615 million, with zero cash infusion to the joint ventures.
Total capital investments, both fab and non-fab are $675 million on a year-to-date basis. Our off balance sheet equipment lease guarantees stand at $891 million at the end of the third quarter, reflecting a reduction of $125 million from Q3 payments, partially offset by a $50 million increase due to the appreciation of the yen in the third quarter. 
Inventory on our balance sheet increased $33 million to $527 million, primarily due to the appreciation of the yen. Measured on a petabyte basis, our SanDisk-owned inventory remains lean at approximately eight basis points. And retail owned channel inventory is also on the low side ending the quarter at a global six weeks. 
I'll now turn to forward-looking commentary. Please note that non-GAAP to GAAP reconciliation tables for all applicable guidance are posted on our website. As we forecast Q4, we believe that demand for NAND is fundamentally strong with the strongest growth drivers being the secular trends in mobile phones and tablets and growth from these end markets primarily shows up in our OEM business. 
We believe that macroeconomic weakness, particularly in the U.S. and Europe, continues to limit growth in our retail demand. However, consumers are still buying as seen in our Q3 retail results and we expect increased retail demand in Q4 for the holiday season. 
So in terms of unit and petabyte demand, we expect good growth from both our OEM and retail channels in the fourth quarter. On the pricing front, we do expect higher price decline in our Q4 than in our Q3 and we have already made certain price adjustments. Taking into account these factors, we expect fourth quarter total revenue to be between $1.25 billion and $1.325 billion and within this total Q4 revenue, we forecast license and royalty revenue between $85 million in $90 million. This fourth quarter forecast would lead to full-year revenue between $4.75 billion and $4.825 billion in the middle of our July forecast of $4.7 billion to $4.9 billion.
Turning to gross margin. There are three key factors that we expect will lead to lower gross margin in the fourth quarter as compared to the third quarter. First, we expect a higher rate of price decline. Second, the yen has depreciated relative to the dollar by approximately 7% since the beginning of our third quarter to present. This increases the dollar cost of the wafers we purchased in the last quarter and these wafers will be reflected in our fourth quarter sales. 
And last, with the 32-nanometer transition completed and more non-captive purchases in Q4, we will see less cost reduction in Q4 as compared to Q3. Our forecasted non-GAAP product gross margin for Q4 is between 39% and 42%, yielding a total non-GAAP gross margin, including license and royalty of 43% to 46%. To put this in perspective, our 32-nanometer transition was faster with higher yields than expected, which accelerated some of our planned second half cost reductions into Q3. Our guidance for Q4 leads to a second half product gross margin above the estimate I've provided in July.
We expect fourth quarter non-GAAP operating expenses between $205 million and $210 million with increases primarily in R&D and in sales and marketing for seasonal retail marketing programs. Our Q4 forecast for non-GAAP other income is approximately $10 million. And we estimate a non-GAAP tax rate of 34% including some onetime benefits. On a GAAP basis, there is the possibility that we will release a substantial portion of our tax valuation allowances in the fourth quarter.
Our total capital investment forecast for fab and non-fab purchases remains at approximately $1.1 billion for 2010, meaning that the investment level in Q4 is estimated at approximately $425 million, reflecting investments for both the 24-nanometer transition and Fab 4 expansion. 
The estimated fourth quarter cash requirements for these investments is expected to be approximately $75 million in loans to the fab joint ventures and approximately $30 million for non-fab purchases. Given this, the fourth quarter should be another good quarter for free cash flow. 
In summary, our third quarter results were outstanding and our fourth quarter gross margins and operating margins are forecasted to be very attractive. We will now open the call for your questions.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Judy, just kind of wanted to dig a little bit deeper here in terms of gross margins. In terms of your guidance, 39% to 42% for the product gross margin, exactly what does that correspond to in terms of cost per bit reduction because I might have faulty ma
componenttext: Judy, just kind of wanted to dig a little bit deeper here in terms of gross margins. In terms of your guidance, 39% to 42% for the product gross margin, exactly what does that correspond to in terms of cost per bit reduction because I might have faulty math here, but it looks like even at 42% gross margin, you're really not modeling or baking or taking into account, very much cost per bit reduction. It looks pretty flat even at the high end of the gross margin guidance. Could you kind of walk me through what exactly your cost per bit reduction sort of visibility is for Q4? And maybe where I have my math wrong?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me help you a little bit. We do expect cost per bit reduction in the fourth quarter. I would tell you that it's in the single-digit percentage as compared to the 13% that we just experienced in the third quarter and that is factored into my 39% t
componenttext: Yes, let me help you a little bit. We do expect cost per bit reduction in the fourth quarter. I would tell you that it's in the single-digit percentage as compared to the 13% that we just experienced in the third quarter and that is factored into my 39% to 42%. And again, that single digit percentage is less than the third quarter because we completed the 32-nanometer transition in the third quarter and we're now starting 24-nanometer transition, which will largely benefit our 2011 costs. And as I mentioned, we also have the impact of the yen and a bit more non-captive purchases that's impacting the total cost per bit reduction in the fourth quarter. But we do expect continued cost reduction per bit and we expect our full year cost-reduction per bit to be well over 40%, full year over full year.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a quick follow-up here for Sanjay or Eli, just about maturation of the X3 architecture here. Are you guys are seeing any kind of incremental benefit now that you're in your third-generation for X3 in terms of basically reducing the billing materials o
componenttext: And a quick follow-up here for Sanjay or Eli, just about maturation of the X3 architecture here. Are you guys are seeing any kind of incremental benefit now that you're in your third-generation for X3 in terms of basically reducing the billing materials or cogs related to cards? Are you seeing an ability to extract a little bit more cost savings on the memory controller size as you shrink? Or are you otherwise able to come away and produce cards with a bit less over provisioning in terms of the content as you go from one generation to the next? Are there any other kind of offsets on gross margin on a card perspective that's kind of helping you out here in Q4 and maybe longer-term in 2011?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On a cog basis, a very important element is what is the maximum diode size and capacity you can fit into the microSD. MicroSD is the highest running volume cost for us and I believe for the industry. So our X3, 32-nanometer X3 two gigabit die fits very ni
componenttext: On a cog basis, a very important element is what is the maximum diode size and capacity you can fit into the microSD. MicroSD is the highest running volume cost for us and I believe for the industry. So our X3, 32-nanometer X3 two gigabit die fits very nicely into a microSD and at 24-nanometer technology, we expect the 64-gigabit to do the same with X3 but not with X2. So X2 versus X3 allows you to shoehorn into a microSD, which is I believe 11 by 15 millimeters and the ability to go to higher capacities without double the number of half capacity chips translates into significant cost reductions.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Vijay Rakesh with Sterne Agee.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: If you could walk us through what the cost reductions were in 4Q outside of -- you said the 32-nanometer transitioners or -- so cost reductions in 4Q and what you seen in the first half?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Vijay, even though we completed the 32-nanometer transition in the third quarter, we will still see benefit from that in our cost reductions in the fourth quarter. That will spill over and benefit our fourth quarter. We'll still have a higher percentage e
componenttext: Vijay, even though we completed the 32-nanometer transition in the third quarter, we will still see benefit from that in our cost reductions in the fourth quarter. That will spill over and benefit our fourth quarter. We'll still have a higher percentage essentially all 32-nanometer in the fourth quarter. So that will be the key driver of fourth quarter cost reductions and then in the first half of 2011, we'll begin to see cost reductions from 24-nanometer.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just to be clear, we completed the 32-nanometer transition by end of the third quarter. So there was still 43-nanometer quarter that was shipped in the third quarter. In fourth quarter, it will be a greater percentage of 32-nanometer product.
componenttext: So just to be clear, we completed the 32-nanometer transition by end of the third quarter. So there was still 43-nanometer quarter that was shipped in the third quarter. In fourth quarter, it will be a greater percentage of 32-nanometer product.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the Fab 4 expansion you said it will be completed by mid-2011, how much expansion will you be doing in terms of wafer fabs let's say in Q4 and let's say by mid-2011 in the first half?
componenttext: And the Fab 4 expansion you said it will be completed by mid-2011, how much expansion will you be doing in terms of wafer fabs let's say in Q4 and let's say by mid-2011 in the first half?

componenttextpreview: We are not exactly providing the specifics of breakdown between Q4 and first half but as we have said in the third quarter, we had started ramping up production of the available green room space in Fab 4 and we need that capacity to meet our requirements
componenttext: We are not exactly providing the specifics of breakdown between Q4 and first half but as we have said in the third quarter, we had started ramping up production of the available green room space in Fab 4 and we need that capacity to meet our requirements in Q3 as well as in Q4 time frame and this expansion will continue and we expect it to be completed by mid-2011.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: When you look at 3Q, what is the wafer capacity in Fab 4? And when you look at 2011 what's the wafer capacity in Fab 4 once it's all completed?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to exact numbers for wafer capacity, we are not providing that but what we have said before is that once Fab 4 completes expansion, and the full capacity is up, our portion of Fab 4 will be at the rate of 2 million, 12-inch, NAND wafers per y
componenttext: With respect to exact numbers for wafer capacity, we are not providing that but what we have said before is that once Fab 4 completes expansion, and the full capacity is up, our portion of Fab 4 will be at the rate of 2 million, 12-inch, NAND wafers per year. And this is, let me be clear, this is Fab 3 and Fab 4 combined.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Our next question will come from Uche Orji with UBS.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eli, let me just start off with asking you about the impact that you expect your SSD product to have. I mean, yesterday, Apple talked about this is not the future of notebook market. I just kind of want to get a sense of what engagements you think you're
componenttext: Eli, let me just start off with asking you about the impact that you expect your SSD product to have. I mean, yesterday, Apple talked about this is not the future of notebook market. I just kind of want to get a sense of what engagements you think you're having right now and specifically, we can talk about tablet market as well, what are these NAND products you have is something that should lead to high engagements for those markets?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the announcement this week, MacBook Air having SSD as standard is I believe very, very important not so much because of MacBook Air itself, but because it's really an industry signal I believe. Apple has done so in the past. Apple was the first company
componenttext: So the announcement this week, MacBook Air having SSD as standard is I believe very, very important not so much because of MacBook Air itself, but because it's really an industry signal I believe. Apple has done so in the past. Apple was the first company to introduce PCs without a floppy disk at a time where everybody thought you've got to have floppys. And I think that going with the standards of notebook PC that has nothing but flash memory, I think it's going to force competitors to much more seriously go in that direction. But we all know that the real driver for mass adoption of flash memory SSD in these type of notebook PCs is very much -- we need to get to a lower cost and that will happen, I believe. Tablets is a different matter. This is really a product category that came out of nowhere. Never was expected to be where it is today even just six months ago and the nice thing about tablets, almost by definition, 10-hour operation, very thin, lightweight, none of the tablets anymore -- actually none of the tablets are designed to use hard disk drives. That was not the case for netbook PCs where we all expected netbook PCs to be, primarily, with flash memory SSD but PSSD, but in fact, turned out to be hard disk drive based. So tablet PC is to the extent that they cannibalized notebook PCs, that's good news for us and for the industry because notebook PCs really are not, today, using SSD to any large extent. As where tablet PCs, to the extent that they cannibalize notebook PCs that could use flash for all industries and certainly for ourselves.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me ask you about pricing. I know someone asked already about his gross margins. Let me just begin to the price elements of what's going to drive gross margins. If ASPs were to hold where they are today, we've seen some decline already in October. What
componenttext: Let me ask you about pricing. I know someone asked already about his gross margins. Let me just begin to the price elements of what's going to drive gross margins. If ASPs were to hold where they are today, we've seen some decline already in October. What will ASP be at the end of the quarter? And also, the elements of non-captive, you ended up with just 1% of non-captive in Q3. What is the availability now from the non-captive markets and how much should we think about demand for non-captive to meet your guidance for the December quarter?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So first on pricing. We're not going to give any specific pricing guidance for the fourth quarter but we do expect higher price decline in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter. Keep in mind that our price decline this year has been quite benig
componenttext: So first on pricing. We're not going to give any specific pricing guidance for the fourth quarter but we do expect higher price decline in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter. Keep in mind that our price decline this year has been quite benign and every quarter this year, the year-over-year price decline has been 20% or less. So the full year price decline even with higher price decline in the fourth quarter is going to be quite low in historical terms. In terms of our non-captive, for the fourth quarter and assumed in our guidance, is that we'll utilize non-captive in the sort of low to mid-single-digit range as a percentage of our total supplies. So up somewhat from the third quarter but not a very large percentage.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one last addition, for Sanjay or Eli. On the TLC, one of the criticisms was that of TLC is that it's really not good enough for the embedded markets. I just want to ask you what your thoughts are on that? And whether you've had any embedded
componenttext: And then just one last addition, for Sanjay or Eli. On the TLC, one of the criticisms was that of TLC is that it's really not good enough for the embedded markets. I just want to ask you what your thoughts are on that? And whether you've had any embedded engagements for TLC? And then also on the TLC price trend going forward, one of the things that was great for you in the June quarter, remember you mentioned you were able to get some premium on this PLC pricing. As you introduce PLC no matter what kind of grade it is, should we expect that to now have more of the pull down on the pricing for you on TLC going forward?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we have said before, that our 3-bits-per-cell memory, what we call X3, really leverages our many, many years of system-level expertise that we have built to deliver and level of orders to the consumers that are high-quality products and actually those
componenttext: As we have said before, that our 3-bits-per-cell memory, what we call X3, really leverages our many, many years of system-level expertise that we have built to deliver and level of orders to the consumers that are high-quality products and actually those products built with our X3 memory meet the specifications of others compete quite well with the specifications that are delivered by others even with their X2, two bit per cell of memory so this is what provides us with the pricing power with our X3 memory. So we really continue to leverage that very well across our product lines and as I referred to in my prepared remarks, we are looking at X3 memory, our 3-bit-per-cell memory, starting to look at that on the embedded applications side as well. So overall, our X3 strategy continues to work well and if to the extent that there is any low-grade memory from others such as the TLC memory from some competitors or other low-grade memory, which may be coming from early, 2x nanometer production of others. That does impact some parts of our business but in the third quarter, we choose not to compete with our high-quality X3 memory with respect to the low pricing that was there from the TLC, the low-grade memory of others.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Daniel Amir with Lazard Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Daniel Amir with Lazard Capital Markets.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, how do you see the tablet market impacting kind of the demand/supply environment next year? And could we potentially see a more benign pricing environment in Q1 because of this?
componenttext: First of all, how do you see the tablet market impacting kind of the demand/supply environment next year? And could we potentially see a more benign pricing environment in Q1 because of this?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We see a lot of design activity in tablets that clearly has been influenced to a large extent by the introduction of the iPad. You all heard Apple's press conference and you know what Steve Jobs thinks of other people's tablets. We think that the market d
componenttext: We see a lot of design activity in tablets that clearly has been influenced to a large extent by the introduction of the iPad. You all heard Apple's press conference and you know what Steve Jobs thinks of other people's tablets. We think that the market does need competition and we will have competition to the iPad as good as the iPad is, it's a great product. And the industry will learn to use Android or other operating systems such as the DRAM operating system to provide tablets with different functionality and we expect that to be a significant force in 2011 and we see great opportunity for us to participate in that.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And with regards to the iNAND, it seems like it's 30% of the OEM business is growing quite significantly. Can you give us a little more clarity on kind of what the momentum that you're seeing there in terms of design activity and where do you really want
componenttext: And with regards to the iNAND, it seems like it's 30% of the OEM business is growing quite significantly. Can you give us a little more clarity on kind of what the momentum that you're seeing there in terms of design activity and where do you really want this business to go? I mean could this be potentially half your OEM business? I mean is that the direction?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I'm not really prepared to provide any specific percentages here, but all I can tell you is that we are actually doing very well with our iNAND design wins, as well as iNAND shipping into volume productions, with respect to smartphones and the design
componenttext: Well I'm not really prepared to provide any specific percentages here, but all I can tell you is that we are actually doing very well with our iNAND design wins, as well as iNAND shipping into volume productions, with respect to smartphones and the design wins in the tablet space. And as Eli mentioned earlier, these are huge demand categories for our business and we are making a very strong in roads here and we believe we are gaining share in this particular segment.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now hear from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll now hear from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eli, you once said that not all NAND is created equally. If I look at the pricing that you guys showed in 3Q, you guys have a lot of people fooled. Your price decline was quite modest relative to what some of the TLC price declines people thought. So my q
componenttext: Eli, you once said that not all NAND is created equally. If I look at the pricing that you guys showed in 3Q, you guys have a lot of people fooled. Your price decline was quite modest relative to what some of the TLC price declines people thought. So my question is, if I look at the MLC price decline pretty widespread up 10% for high-grade OEM grade and then they're down 5% on the low end. So what is the barrier to otherwise -- I mean how sustainable is this GAAP in your view moving forward?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that NAND is getting more and more difficult and make and it is absolutely, I firmly believe that the combination of Toshiba and SanDisk really have superior NAND technology and products. Of course, other people think the same of theirs way and ar
componenttext: I think that NAND is getting more and more difficult and make and it is absolutely, I firmly believe that the combination of Toshiba and SanDisk really have superior NAND technology and products. Of course, other people think the same of theirs way and are entitled to that. But Toshiba and SanDisk combined generate about 40% of the world output and our own quality standards are very high as we penetrate more and more OEM business, OEMs major OEMs, have very high standards for quality. And we have really, to a large extent, stayed away from playing in these low quality, low prices markets. Now I've also said many times, that I believe it's very important for the industry to have continuos price reductions that are in-line with cost reductions. The industry has had the benefit of really two generations of technology from the 43-nanometer to the 32-nanometer and next year, 24, 27 with very, very substantial cost reductions that are leading to the very excellent gross margins, which has been wonderful for stable pricing and so on. On the other hand, there's no question about it that some markets do require, like SSD, require some price reductions that take advantage of these cost reductions and I used to accelerate these new markets as well as broadened appeal to a new strata of customers. So I think, price reductions like we said this year, we think the industry total price reduction year-to-year is about 20%. That's very unusual. It has helped the industry recover it's health but the cost reductions really do allow us and the industry, I believe, in 2011 to get closer to what some of these new markets need to have. So in general, actually I feel very good about our ability and for the industry to continue cost reductions through technology, through execution of our 24-nanometer with 3-bits-per-cell and we expected this will allow us to be a very competitive player in these new markets in 2011.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the second one for Judy, I don't want you to guide cost reduction into 1Q, but I just wanted to understand the linearity of the 24-nanometer transition that you guys just started in 4Q. I mean, typically, these transitions, they happen over multiple q
componenttext: And the second one for Judy, I don't want you to guide cost reduction into 1Q, but I just wanted to understand the linearity of the 24-nanometer transition that you guys just started in 4Q. I mean, typically, these transitions, they happen over multiple quarters. Is it fair to assume that the linearity of this transition, it's going to be through the next -- through the three quarters into next year?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The transition will definitely take several quarters. As to exactly the linearity of that transition, it's a little bit early to predict that at this point in time.
componenttext: The transition will definitely take several quarters. As to exactly the linearity of that transition, it's a little bit early to predict that at this point in time.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Daniel Berenbaum with Auriga USA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Daniel Berenbaum with Auriga USA.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on the 3-bit-per-cell actually. Did you talk about what -- is any 3-bits-per-cell being used in embedded right now or what percentage of your embedded business is 3-bit-per-cell?
componenttext: A couple of questions on the 3-bit-per-cell actually. Did you talk about what -- is any 3-bits-per-cell being used in embedded right now or what percentage of your embedded business is 3-bit-per-cell?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we did not specifically break down what percentage of 3-bit-per-cell is in embedded. Overall, utilization of 3-bit-per-cell for all of our business, OEM and retail business combined for 2010 is greater than 50%. And in terms of the embedded business,
componenttext: No, we did not specifically break down what percentage of 3-bit-per-cell is in embedded. Overall, utilization of 3-bit-per-cell for all of our business, OEM and retail business combined for 2010 is greater than 50%. And in terms of the embedded business, we have started shipping our 3-bit-per-cell for certain embedded applications. Most of the embedded applications that shipping today is still with 2-bit-per-cell and this is progress that we look forward to making in the future, with respect to our superior 3-bit-per-cell technology.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you sort of point as maybe across the next year how fast do you expect 3-bit-per-cell to grow in embedded and what applications it's suitable for in embedded?
componenttext: Can you sort of point as maybe across the next year how fast do you expect 3-bit-per-cell to grow in embedded and what applications it's suitable for in embedded?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think regarding next year, in terms of the progress of 3-bit-per-cell, we'll probably provide you some color on that in the January/February time frame. In regard to the 3-bit-per-cell embedded application, of course, we are continuing to work on that i
componenttext: I think regarding next year, in terms of the progress of 3-bit-per-cell, we'll probably provide you some color on that in the January/February time frame. In regard to the 3-bit-per-cell embedded application, of course, we are continuing to work on that in the mobile handsets, the smartphone space and particularly with respect to high-capacity iNAND products.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit of technology -- just a little bit of technology. I'll try to keep it very simple. Our 3-bit-per-cell embedded iNAND actually can write and very often relies on the writing data into binary SLC, not just 2-bits and certainly n
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit of technology -- just a little bit of technology. I'll try to keep it very simple. Our 3-bit-per-cell embedded iNAND actually can write and very often relies on the writing data into binary SLC, not just 2-bits and certainly not 3-bits but writing into 1-bit-per-cell and then in background, writing it into 3-bits-per-cell. And that is what we call flash caching and adaptive flash memory where we adapt the iNAND to that specific application. That is where we have this benefit that our X3 can look in a application superior to somebody else's X2 because actually we have this combination, which is very nicely covered by early patents between writing in binary and back around writing into X3. So this is where you see tremendous advantage to experience and to the system know how that we've been talking about.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just a more near-term question looking out to Q4. Judy, you mentioned the percentage of non-captive capacity growing but it seems that bit shipments in this quarter were at least the bit shipping growth was relatively low and again just sor
componenttext: And then maybe just a more near-term question looking out to Q4. Judy, you mentioned the percentage of non-captive capacity growing but it seems that bit shipments in this quarter were at least the bit shipping growth was relatively low and again just sort of doing some of the math it seems like bit shipments next quarter would need to grow at 40% plus to hit that kind of 75% for the full year that you had talked about having enough internal capacity for. So am I thinking about that the right way? And I guess the question is, how certain are you that you're going to need to go outside for non- captive capacity?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so you're right that in total, our third quarter bit growth was a little bit less than we've typically seen in the third quarter so I'll talk about the third quarter first and then the fourth quarter. In the third quarter, we actually were quite ple
componenttext: Okay, so you're right that in total, our third quarter bit growth was a little bit less than we've typically seen in the third quarter so I'll talk about the third quarter first and then the fourth quarter. In the third quarter, we actually were quite pleased with the bit growth in the retail part of our business. We saw strong bit growth sequentially in the retail business. In the OEM business, we saw more modest bit growth but we had good bit growth overall in the mobile handset part of our OEM business, and that was offset somewhat by the fact that we chose not to participate, as Sanjay described, in some of the low-price business in the white label card and also in the Wafer business. So that impacted somewhat our bit growth there. Also, I'll also mention that our bit growth and OEM in the third quarter was also impacted somewhat by the fact that there were some non-memory component shortages early in the third quarter that limited somewhat the shipment of certain handsets. And when those handsets shipments were limited, that also then limited somewhat our sales of NAND into those handsets. We believe that, that issue has been solved in the marketplace and that's not an issue in the fourth quarter. So turning to the fourth quarter, in the fourth quarter, we believe that we will have strong bit growth, both in the retail part of our business and in the OEM part of our business and so, we're not giving any specific guidance but I think you are thinking about it correctly as you try to model your bit growth for the year.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So where are those bits that you didn't ship in Q3? Because the inventory didn't go up that much, so I guess my question is where are those bits? Are they in inventory at handset manufacturers or are they in inventories someplace else?
componenttext: So where are those bits that you didn't ship in Q3? Because the inventory didn't go up that much, so I guess my question is where are those bits? Are they in inventory at handset manufacturers or are they in inventories someplace else?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our inventory is lean. It would have been even leaner if we had shipped more in the third quarter and in fact, that is why we think we do need a little bit of non-captive in the fourth quarter and more non- captive in the fourth quarter than in the
componenttext: Well, our inventory is lean. It would have been even leaner if we had shipped more in the third quarter and in fact, that is why we think we do need a little bit of non-captive in the fourth quarter and more non- captive in the fourth quarter than in the third quarter.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you had sort of implicitly expect inventory to go down in Q4?
componenttext: So you had sort of implicitly expect inventory to go down in Q4?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that it will actually go down. It's possibly could go up some because remember, we're still ramping Fab 4. So we will have more bits coming in from Fab 4 even late in the quarter. And also, just in terms of the dollar value of the inventory,
componenttext: I don't know that it will actually go down. It's possibly could go up some because remember, we're still ramping Fab 4. So we will have more bits coming in from Fab 4 even late in the quarter. And also, just in terms of the dollar value of the inventory, I can't predict what will happen to the yen over the next three months, but the appreciation of the yen also puts pressure on the dollar value of the inventory.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Kate Kotlarsky with Goldman Sachs, has our next question.
componenttext: And Kate Kotlarsky with Goldman Sachs, has our next question.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I have is around the Fab 5. And just wanted to ask you guys, you do seem to be pretty bullish on the outlook for NAND demand next year but you sound a little bit cautious on, not the Fab 5 ramp but at least the commitment to Fab 5 and h
componenttext: The first question I have is around the Fab 5. And just wanted to ask you guys, you do seem to be pretty bullish on the outlook for NAND demand next year but you sound a little bit cautious on, not the Fab 5 ramp but at least the commitment to Fab 5 and how much you think you might ramp next year. So I was just hoping you could reconcile those two things for us to kind of -- the cautious approach to Fab 5 yet being very bullish on NAND demand next year?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we said, we definitely believe in the fundamentals being strong for our business in the smartphone, the tablets, and the rest of the business as well for next year. With respect to Fab 5, we are exercising the discipline and we want to make sure that w
componenttext: As we said, we definitely believe in the fundamentals being strong for our business in the smartphone, the tablets, and the rest of the business as well for next year. With respect to Fab 5, we are exercising the discipline and we want to make sure that we assess our demand projections before we really commit to the start of the Fab 5 production. Keep in mind that Fab 5 is currently under construction and we have lead time available for us to really make decisions regarding the start of that Fab 5.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: This relates to the comment that Eli made earlier about having to have cost declines and ASP declines in order to drive some of the demand in applications like solid state drives and tablets et cetera. I was just curious how you guys are thinking between
componenttext: This relates to the comment that Eli made earlier about having to have cost declines and ASP declines in order to drive some of the demand in applications like solid state drives and tablets et cetera. I was just curious how you guys are thinking between the balance of having to take ASPs down, maybe for you guys and for the industry as a whole in order to drive some of these applications. And maybe, what kind of ASP declines do you think the industry needs to get to in order to have meaningful content growth in some of these applications like tablets and smartphones next year?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think this is a very good question. Price declines, as we know, healthy for the industry growth if they are in-line with cost declines and if they are too slow with regard to cost decline, that start slowing down growth. If they're too fast, they create
componenttext: I think this is a very good question. Price declines, as we know, healthy for the industry growth if they are in-line with cost declines and if they are too slow with regard to cost decline, that start slowing down growth. If they're too fast, they create problems for the return of investment on our capacity. I would say, in the fourth quarter this year, SSD is not where we thought it would be a year ago because of the pricing during this year. And SSD we all know, needs to have a lower price point in what I said earlier is that the industry and certainly, SanDisk has a significantly lower cost structure as evidenced by our product gross margin in the third quarter and what I'm saying is it is very important, if you're looking long term for sustainable growth with profitability and good return investment, it's very important for us and I can't talk for the industry but for ourself to have a balance that to be overly greedy frankly on the upside so that the downside as we know, the up cycles in this thing are much more mild and acceptable. But I know, not ringing any number all I'm saying is 20% price decline for 2010 has been very important to get the industry back into health but the industry has also done very well in terms of cost reductions far exceeding 20%.  And I think it will be healthy for the industry, and I'm speaking really for SanDisk, to have a balance between maximizing gross margins on the one hand and growing our market for the long term.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in your view, the kind of 20% ASP reduction that we saw this year is probably not enough to drive meaningful content growth next year and that we'd probably need to see something greater than that maybe is that 50% but it's probably not 20%. Would that
componenttext: So in your view, the kind of 20% ASP reduction that we saw this year is probably not enough to drive meaningful content growth next year and that we'd probably need to see something greater than that maybe is that 50% but it's probably not 20%. Would that be a fair characterization?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Craig Ellis with Caris & Company.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Craig Ellis with Caris & Company.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eli, you touched on PC adoption, for SSDs. I was wondering if you might just look out into the future and give us some idea when you think PC SSD adoption might get to some benchmark level, let's say around 20%.
componenttext: Eli, you touched on PC adoption, for SSDs. I was wondering if you might just look out into the future and give us some idea when you think PC SSD adoption might get to some benchmark level, let's say around 20%.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it all hinges on really the 24-nanometer and let's say, the 20-nanometer nodes. The 24-nanometer, the cost structure is very attractive, I believe, for SSD, particularly if one can deliver SSD with reasonable performance with 3-bits-per-cell, but
componenttext: I think it all hinges on really the 24-nanometer and let's say, the 20-nanometer nodes. The 24-nanometer, the cost structure is very attractive, I believe, for SSD, particularly if one can deliver SSD with reasonable performance with 3-bits-per-cell, but even with 2-bits, it gets a lot closer to where the mass market develops. At 20-nanometer, I think, the mass markets really begins to take off. So we are within one to two generations, I believe, of having the right cost structure and performance, I believe, because performance is constantly improving, actually at a very nice rate and reliability problems are being addressed very nicely throughout the industry. That I believe within the next one to two generations, you're going to see a significant move on the upside for SSD and I don't mean the enterprise SSD because as we know, that's already taking place, because they can tolerate SLC pricing, which is, of course, significantly higher per gigabyte.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Judy, as I look at the cash CapEx this year, it strikes me that the mix of cash CapEx is far lower than anything I can remember seeing back to 2004, which is pretty remarkable and I'm wondering, is the mix of CapEx funding with such a large porti
componenttext: And then Judy, as I look at the cash CapEx this year, it strikes me that the mix of cash CapEx is far lower than anything I can remember seeing back to 2004, which is pretty remarkable and I'm wondering, is the mix of CapEx funding with such a large portion of it coming from joint venture working capital something that's sustainable and if it is, then what does SanDisk plan to do with the excess cash that it looks like it will be piling up as we look out to 2011 and 2012?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would tell you that there has been growth, real growth in the cash generation power of the joint ventures, particularly as they have matured and become more depreciated. At the same time, some of the capital investments that we are making this year such
componenttext: I would tell you that there has been growth, real growth in the cash generation power of the joint ventures, particularly as they have matured and become more depreciated. At the same time, some of the capital investments that we are making this year such as the fab four expansion in the second half of 2010, some of that will require some cash infusion in the early part of 2011. So there will be some more cash that needs to be put into the joint ventures in the 2011 timeframe. I think that our business model is a little different obviously than the business model of a company that owns its fabs directly and it makes it a little bit hard to decipher but you have to keep in mind that instead of seeing the depreciation in our results, you're seeing the operating cash flow of the joint ventures themselves. And so, I think that's natural, and we feel very good about the relatively minimal amount of cash that we've had to put in this year.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So next year's cash component will increase but would it increase to levels that are below past normative levels or would we move back more towards normative levels, Judy?
componenttext: So next year's cash component will increase but would it increase to levels that are below past normative levels or would we move back more towards normative levels, Judy?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it will still be better than it has been in the past but exactly how much cash we have to put in next year is still not known at this point because we haven't really formulated our capital investment plans for next year, including as Sanjay descri
componenttext: I think it will still be better than it has been in the past but exactly how much cash we have to put in next year is still not known at this point because we haven't really formulated our capital investment plans for next year, including as Sanjay described, that we don't have a ramp plan decided for Fab 5. So we'll have to really provide more details on that in our February Analyst Day.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That question will come from Bob Gujavarty with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: That question will come from Bob Gujavarty with Deutsche Bank.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Judy, could you rank the relative weights on margins? What's going to weigh on margins between ASP declines offsetting cogs, yen appreciation, and then finally, non-captive? Can you rank them for us on,which is most significant to least significant?
componenttext: Judy, could you rank the relative weights on margins? What's going to weigh on margins between ASP declines offsetting cogs, yen appreciation, and then finally, non-captive? Can you rank them for us on,which is most significant to least significant?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to rank them from one to four for you but I will say, that the non-captive is probably the smallest factor in the fourth quarter. And really, the two primary factors are that we do expect increased price decline and we do expect a lower rate
componenttext: I'm not going to rank them from one to four for you but I will say, that the non-captive is probably the smallest factor in the fourth quarter. And really, the two primary factors are that we do expect increased price decline and we do expect a lower rate of cost declined. And there's a couple of factors that lead to the lower rate of cost decline including the timing of the technology transitions and the yen, as I described.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then it just a quick follow-up. I mean, just assuming normal seasonality, would it be fair to say that you;'d have less need for non-captive capacity in the first of the year compared to the second half of the year?
componenttext: And then it just a quick follow-up. I mean, just assuming normal seasonality, would it be fair to say that you;'d have less need for non-captive capacity in the first of the year compared to the second half of the year?

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to predict. Our usage of non-captive at this point for next year that might more likely be true for the first quarter in terms of typical historical first quarter seasonality, hard to say for the first half.
componenttext: It's really hard to predict. Our usage of non-captive at this point for next year that might more likely be true for the first quarter in terms of typical historical first quarter seasonality, hard to say for the first half.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If the yen and dollar stabilize at these levels, will the exchange rate be a further headwind in heading into 1Q or -- I'm just trying to figure out how long the tail is in terms of the exchange rate move.
componenttext: If the yen and dollar stabilize at these levels, will the exchange rate be a further headwind in heading into 1Q or -- I'm just trying to figure out how long the tail is in terms of the exchange rate move.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If it stabilizes at these levels, it has continued, the yen has continued to appreciate, let's say, over the last month. So yes, there would be a little bit more of a headwind relative to the average wafer cost purchased in Q3 and recognized in the fourth
componenttext: If it stabilizes at these levels, it has continued, the yen has continued to appreciate, let's say, over the last month. So yes, there would be a little bit more of a headwind relative to the average wafer cost purchased in Q3 and recognized in the fourth quarter cost of sales. I want to point out however, though that really, the yen has appreciated a fair amount, not just in the last quarter but really in the last one to two years. And that is all incorporated in our 48% product gross margins this quarter so that's something to keep in mind in terms of how well we have performed.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's question-and-answer session. I'd now like to turn the call back over to management for any closing comments.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's question-and-answer session. I'd now like to turn the call back over to management for any closing comments.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, this is Eli. I just want to say this has been an incredible two year ride with all of you guys. And Sanjay and SanDisk have an absolutely great future. So we go here with, "Go SanDisk". Thank you.
componenttext: Okay, this is Eli. I just want to say this has been an incredible two year ride with all of you guys. And Sanjay and SanDisk have an absolutely great future. So we go here with, "Go SanDisk". Thank you.

headline: SanDisk Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, all.
componenttext: Thank you, all.
